passage.text: Platelet count and Interleukin 6 Gene polymorphism in healthy subjects
The first time we have described genetical impact on basal platelet counts, which appears to be partially influenced by polymorphisms of the IL-6 gene, even in cases of no inflammation.

The onset and persistence of inflammatory arthritis (IA) is heavily influenced by decreased hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal activity, particularly a blunted response to immune system activation. Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), along with its sulfate ester, are the most frequently found steroid hormones produced by the human adrenal cortex and are likely to have biological significance. However, some studies conducted in Finnish women show lower DHEAS levels before the earliest female MDHDH or other reports indicate normalised DHT cells out this same

Measuring fertilization-induced calcium transients provides a novel experimental technique for studying C. elegans. Researchers can now examine thousands of mutants with fertilizer defects to determine whether there are any defects in the calcium transfer. The availability of forward genetic (gene knockout and RNAi) methods in Cryobacterium enables the testing of proteins believed to be involved in this crucial step of embryogenesis.
